results.title: Picasso is 90
results.brief_description: Traces Picasso’s life from childhood to old age showing a retrospective of his paintings and sculpture filmed on location at the Pushkin Museum in Moscow, the Hermitage in Leningrad, the Museum of Modern Art in New York. Some glimpses of Picasso’s personal life are provided with comments by his son Claude Picasso, his former wife and Don Luis Miquel Dominguin, the famous Spanish bullfighter. Includes film clips showing scenes of Gertrude Stein, Georges Braque, the Spanish Civil War, the bombing of Guernica in the 1900’s, and Russian Communists applauding the political sympathies of Picasso. Written and reported by Charles Collingwood.

results.title: Picasso (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Anthony Flanagan, Michael Redington and Associated Television
results.brief_description: Sir Kenneth Clark introduces paintings by the Spanish painter Pable Picasso. Filmed in the Tate Gallery, London, where the paintings are displayed in chronological order, we see how, as he matured, his approach changed. From 30 selected paintings, Sir Kenneth shows Picasso’s earliest work, while still in his teens, through various impressionistic works and the great era of his murals to his present works.

results.title: Picasso
results.brief_description: A dream-like appraisal of the life and work of Pablo Picasso, a universally acclaimed modern artist whose development through so many styles of painting and other forms of artistic expression had a revolutionary impact on the way we see things. This program traces his 80 years of painting, particularly his fascination with the mythological figure of the minotaur intertwined with the history, events and political life of Spain during his lifetime and his own personal concerns. It also focuses on the development of his portrait series, his fascination with his models, including his young lover Marie-Therese, and his coded exploration of humanity tender, cruel and solitary. Such landmark works as “Guernica”, “Las Meninas” and his many portraits both in painting and sculpture are analysed in great detail in this documentary with thorough discussion of the history and thematic concerns of the pieces in the narration written by Jean Michel Michelena.

results.title: Pic et Pic et Colegram = Eeeny, Meeny, Miney Moe
results.brief_description:
Two small Jewish children in Nazi-occupied France are placed with a sombre family of Protestant farmers in the Cevennes to hide from persecutions. Further viewing: The documentary ‘Weapons of the Spirit’ (# 2048011, Vhs).

Credits: Producer, Pierre Meurisse ; director, Rachel Weinberg ; writer, Rachel Weinberg ; photography; Jean-Jacques Renon ; music, Georghe Zamfir, Janko Nilovic.
Cast: Monique Chaumette, Henri Garcin, Hans Meyer, Laurence Klejman, Ivan Erimitchoi, Francine Berge [narration].

results.title: Pic-nic
results.creator_credit: Stella Babirz, David Atkinson, John Bird, Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Film Victoria
results.brief_description: One of the seven deadly sins, gluttony, is explored when a group of aristocrats picnic together. Not content just to eat the food, the guests turn to their classical environment to devour and eventually turn on themselves. An adventure with appetite. Voices by Vanessa Kortlang, Allannah Hill, Noel Crombie, Stella Babirz.

results.title: Piano lessons
results.creator_credit: Jonothan Cullinane, Trevor Haysom and Toucan Films
results.brief_description: A young boy of thirteen, Craig (Willy Simeon), is less than excited when his birthday present isn’t quite what he’d been expecting - an old out of tune piano. His efforts to learn the piano are thwarted and Craig’s life is not the same when it is realised that the piano has quite a demonic sensibility. The piano drinks, smokes, kills the cat and suffers from several personality disorders that include jealousy…so what is the likelihood that the piano will be excited by Craig’s decision to use an electric piano for his debut stage performance? Cast includes: Ian Watkin, Brenda Kendall, Craig Parker, Raoul MacIntosh, Jessica James. Written by Jonothan Cullinane.
